content:
Tools>Settings>Composition>HTML Style

Set the size to 'Medium' because you do not want to force a large size on recipients.

To set up a 'medium' size of your choice do this:

Settings > General scroll to 'Language & Appearance' section click on 'Advanced'

Whatever size you are currently using you need to increase it. In example below I'm suggesting to first try size 16 and see if it looks right for you. You need to set same setting for both 'Latin' (western encoding) and 'Other Writing Systems' (unicode encoding).

  • Select 'Fonts for: choose 'Latin'
  • Set 'Proportional Size' to eg: 16
  • Set 'Monospace Size' to 16
  • Set minimum size to 14 (allows a bit smaller but stops smaller font size)
  • Now set identical settings for 'Fonts for:' and select 'Other Writing Systems' (bottom of drop down list).
  • Set 'Proportional Size' to eg: 16
  • Set 'Monospace Size' to 16
  • Set minimum size to 14 (allows a bit smaller but stops smaller font size)
  • Finally, ReSelect 'Fonts for: choose 'Latin'
  • click on 'OK' to save new settings.

From now onwards the 'medium' font displayed in Message Pane and when you compose a message will be size 16px.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Close any Write message windows that are already open because they will not pick up the new settings. Then open a new Write message and start typing. Does the medium font using a size 16px work better for you or is it still a bit too small ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
What server settings are you using for the outgoing smtp?

  • Account Settings
  • Left pane scroll to bottom and clickon 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)'
  • You should see a list on the right of all outgoing servers.
  • Select the one used for account and click on 'Edit'
  • Please post an image of outgoing server settings.

Do you have more than one account using outlook server. ? In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Copy all that section and paste into t his question OR post an image showing the info.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: It is valid, but mostly useless. The filters, and I assume search, acts on the first instance in encounters and as most emails have more than one received header the result is it fails at least as often as it succeeds.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
By 'labels' do you mean 'Tags' ?

If yes, then the list of 'Tags' is in the profile name folder in the 'prefs.js' file.

On computer which has list of 20 tags: In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' section - half way is 'Profile Folder' - click on 'Open Folder' button
  • A new window opens showing the contents of you 'profile name' folder.
  • Scroll down and look for the 'prefs.js' file
  • Open the 'prefs.js' file using Notepad.
  • Scroll down and look for where you see the first line starting with:
  • user_pref("mailnews.tags.
  • Highlight all the lines that start with that preference then right click on the highlighted lines and select 'Copy'
  • Then close the 'prefs.js' file. No need to save anything because nothing has changed.
  • Open a new Notepad file, right click and select paste.
  • Now you should have a complete list.
  • Save the file as filename 'Tags' to an external drive so you can use it to move to new computer.

On new/other computer:

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' section - half way is 'Profile Folder' - click on 'Open Folder' button
  • A new window opens showing the contents of you 'profile name' folder.
  • Exit Thunderbird now - this is important
  • Scroll down and look for the 'prefs.js' file
  • Suggest you make a copy of that 'prefs.js' file and save to desktop as a backup - just in case you make an error.
  • Open the 'prefs.js' file using Notepad.
  • Scroll down and look for where you see the first line starting with:
  • user_pref("mailnews.tags.
  • Access the saved 'Tags' file.
  • Copy all the lines: user_pref("mailnews.tags.
  • In the opened 'prefs.js' file look for the lines that start with user_pref("mailnews.tags.
  • You need to delete them and then in the same space paste in the copied lines, (or highlight all of them and use right click and Paste to overwrite) so you now see a complete list of all those lines.
  • There shoud not be any empty lines.
  • Save the file.

Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Just in case anyone else reads this and wants to know the answer....

How do I delete one of my many email adresses in Thunderbird?

  • Account Settings
  • Select name of account in left pane
  • click on 'Account Actions'
  • Click on 'Remove account'

What OS are you using? what version of Thunderbird are you using?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
The profile folder and the folder with the program files are separate, and uninstalling or reinstalling the program doesn't affect the profile folder that contains all user data.

If you wish to backup profile then your profile should be located here: Mac OS X Profile folders are located here:

  • ~/Library/Thunderbird/Profiles/<Profile name>/

The tilde character (~) refers to the current user's Home folder, so ~/Library is the /Macintosh HD/Users/<username>/Library folder.

Suggest you backup the 'Thunderbird' folder in the 'Library' as then contains absolutely everything including the 'profiles.ini' file etc.

This info may help:

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-thunderbird-on-mac

You can get a fresh download for MAC from this link, you just need to make sure you choose appropriate language and the MACOS option.

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It sounds like you have 'threaded' option selected. If you have not expanded that thread to see all the subthreads then you will see the following:

If top level thread is collapsed - it will have a right pointing chevron to the left of the Subject.

  • If email thread has new unread mail, that top level thread will have bold text and will be underlined indicating it has new unread mail.
  • If email has unread mail, that top level thread will have normal text and will be underlined indicating it has unread mail.
  • If email has only read mail, that top level thread will have normal text and will Not be underlined indicating it has only read mail.

If you expand a collapsed thread by clicking on the right pointing chevron, it will change to downward pointing chevron and will display all threads indented. If there are any new unreads threads they will get appended to conversation and will appear in bold text. You will also see a green dot in the 'sort by read status' column for that new unread email. Each email in thread will display the date for that email.

If you quickly want to see just unread mail then you can use the Quick Filter Bar filters.

  • Click on the 'Show only unread messages' icon button (looks like an envelope)

To go back to showing full list, click on the same button again to remove the filter. This is actually a really useful option if you want to see all unread both new and previously received but still unread mail.

If you do not want to use threaded view then switch it off and all emails will appear as a list sorted by whatever option you choose. So if you want new mail at the top then use:

  • View > Sort by > Date, Descending, Unthreaded
creator: Toad-Hall

content: First, if the system crashed, there is the possibility that Thunderbird was running at the time and the profile may be corrupted from the crash. If the profile is okay, you should be able to activate it by clicking help>troubleshootinginformation, scroll dow to 'rofiles', click 'about:profiles', click 'create profile', click next, enter a name, such as 'myprofile', and click browse button to locate and select the desired profile. If the profile still does not work, the old message files can be moved to a new profile. Post back with status after checking.
creator: davidsk

content: Do NOT touch that file. It has nothing to do with speed. That file tells Thunderbird where the active profile is. If you incorrectly modify or delete the file, thunderbird will not start. I am not the speed guru here, but large message files are often part of the issue.
creator: davidsk

content: I suggest you update the account settings to use the server names Microsoft require. pop3.live.com is not it. See https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/pop-imap-and-smtp-settings-for-outlook-com-d088b986-291d-42b8-9564-9c414e2aa040
